title: How to safely implement a power supply for an electronics project - Quora

response.answer_text: How do you safely implement a power supply for an electronics project? A2A Depends on the project. I used to build 100w power amps, the power supply was a massive transformer, several massive capacitors, a bridge rectifier, and one or two more bits. Built into an earthed aluminium chassis, and correctly fused. Nowadays if I build a microcontroller project, they can mostly be supplied by 5v at 50mA - 1000mA. If mains powered, I use a USB brick. If battery powered, I use a small power bank - the auto-on versions, generally without switches. If power demand is below 80mA I have the microcontroller take a current pulse periodically to keep the bank turned on.

This is one of those “if you have to ask …” questions. Design, even build your project using a bench power supply, check the required current. Then go and buy a suitably rated sealed unit power supply. Project works, everyone is safe. Result!
